description: Erection of part single storey, part two storey rear and side extensions
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The facing materials to be used in the construction of the building shall be those specified on the application form and approved drawings or such other materials as have been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the development is commenced and shall thereafter be retained as such.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or reenacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the flank walls of the extension hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments, including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The roof of the extension hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a dwellinghouse.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2016) Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a detached dwelling.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Impact on Parking.The application proposes the demolition of an existing single storey conservatory and the erection of a full width, 4.5m deep (central projection of 5.1m), single storey flat roof extension. The extension would be set in from the shared boundaries by approx 1m. The extension at the highest point would be approx 3.5m reducing to approx 3.1m. There is a tree identified as T1 on the submitted drawings.  A such, a condition has been imposed requiring that this tree be protected during the construction of the extension. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The application would result in the loss of available garage space, however, off-street parking space would be retained to the front of the property. The loss of the garage would result in the loss of available cycle storage space, however, there is sufficient space in the rear garden, with access from the side of the property, to provide safe and secure cycle parking. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.There have been 2 objections to the proposal the points raised can be summarised as follows1) The development when taken together with other permissions / consents would result in a much enlarged dwelling out of character with neighbouring properties2) loss of light3) concern the property would be used as a large HMOIt is important to note that a recent approval, the Erection of hip to gable and rear dormer roof extensions and installation of 1 x roof light to front roof slope to facilitate loft conversion and replacement garage was permitted development (19/03102/CPU)There is an outstanding application for a replacement garage (20/03300/HOU), however, it is to be noted that the footprint of the proposed garage is similar to garages / outbuildings in the immediate vicinity. Concerns relating to a possible use of the extended dwelling as a HMO is not relevant to the assessment of this application. Any change would either be permitted development, or if a large HMO require planning permission.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Impact on parking provisionWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Neighbouring properties have been extended at ground floor in a way comparable to that proposed by the applicant. Whilst the proposed extension, at a ground floor, would not be in strict accordance with the guidance in the SPD, it would nonetheless be in keeping with extensions in the immediate vicinity of the site. With regards to the first floor element, it is proposed that the property is extended at first floor along the side of the property with a projection from the rear. The proposal includes for a gap of 1m from the boundary of the site so as to avoid a terracing impact and has been designed to accord with the 45 degree guidance (daylight/sunlight).The development would remove space available for the parking of a vehicle, however, it is evident that there is sufficient space remaining at the front of the property to provide off-street parking. The proposed extension would result in a property which would appear, and is, larger than the neighbouring properties, however, it is considered that the larger property would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
Work description includes "Driveway amendments"Please prtovide full details of all changes made to the driveway.Both existing and proposed driveway plans are required.

Please provide a copy of block/site plan scaled 1:500/1:200 showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block/site plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.Please note the submitted plan P-13998-101-A-SITE PLAN  is to incorrect scale and the scale bar given does not scale correctly.

As the proposed development is within flood zones 2 and 3 or on a site of more than 1ha, you are required to complete a Flood Risk form before the application can be assessed.  For further information and guidance on any aspects of undertaking a Flood Risk Assessment please contact the Environment Agency by visiting their website at http://planningguidance.communities.gov.uk/blog/guidance/flood-risk-and-coastal-change/site-specific-flood-risk-assessment-checklist/
Please be advised that a fee of £116 is required for this application. This can be paid either online at www.kingston.gov.uk or by calling our Customer Service Team on 020 8547 5002
